data.text: The Ultimate Sun Protection for Bike Touring

What do you all use for sun protection? My nose and lips burn easily even after reapplying sunscreen. I‚Äôm thinking of using a gator but was wondering if it would fog up my sunglasses. Maybe a good sunblock that doesn‚Äôt wash away with sweat?
Visor on helmet. Might prefer a mask or buff in peak afternoon sun-in-face ride over applying products.
data.author: Bravos Louis

data.text: visor + a good beard
data.author: Roy Brubaker

data.text: Banana Boat 100 spf. I burn quick and easy and this stuff stayed working thru 6+ of riding and sweating.
data.author: Daniel Trump

data.text: This stuff is kinda the ultimate. I used to get this plus a "faces" cream (Banana Boat or Neutrogena) 'cause regular sport cream stays kinda caky and can sweat into your eyes) After I found Coppertone 30/50 spray, I was hooked though. No more massaging.
data.author: Chris Davis

data.text:
I wear a Da Brim that fits under my helmet keeping the sun off my head all the way around. Or as in this ad you can wear it over the helmet. https://dabrim.com/collections/cycling-products/products/sporty-cycling?gclid=CjwKCAjw9NeXBhAMEiwAbaY4loQxKXHSoB1KYoI4MaRNt5Im2VDKTvOiiwi2VEZ7Azw28PWF3br6fxoCr3MQAvD_BwE
Sporty Cycling Helmet Visor Brim
dabrim.com
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: We are going to start using our Dabrim shades to get used to them before our Katy Trail ride in October.
data.author: Gordon Keller

data.text: I burn easily and Da Brim helped a tremendous amount. I biked the Southern Tier last fall and never burned! Da Brim, long sleeve SPF30+ shirts and SPF sunscreen on really sunny days (most of the trip)
data.author: Bill Debs

data.text: I like the ‚Äúdon‚Äôt hit me‚Äù florescent yellow
data.author: Bill Debs

data.text: I see this one is the sporty model. They are currently sold out of the larger original. Do you feel this one gives you enough shade while riding?
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: Yes! And being it's on top of the helmet instead of under it, it's much cooler in the oncoming wind.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text:
Before I got my first dabrim I just took a hat with a wide round brim and cut the top out leaving the head band part to wear under my helmet.https://www.instructables.com/A-DIY-Sun-Protective-Brim-for-a-Bicycle-Helmet/ This link shows sorta like what I did.
A DIY Sun-Protective Brim for a Bicycle Helmet
instructables.com
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Thanks for the info
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: I use coconut oil about twice in a day and had a shemagh scarf wrapped to only leave my eyes open. Worked well enough in the high altitude sun of the Indian Himalayas.
data.author: AniSh Joseph

data.text: Recofit makes sleeves to cover up your arms too.
data.author: David J. Syrotiak

data.text: Cycling cap for my skull (it peeks through), Coppertone 30spf spray (spray liberally on arms, legs, back and front of neck, ears, apply to fingers and cover nose, under eyes, rub in.) Anything for lips. Blistex stick with any spf. Reapply after 'X' hours. Try to recharge in the shade for a bit 'cause you can't go forever. P.S. your lips are always going to chap and swell. They're like your neck or knees... they're always out in the open. Do what you can.
data.author: Chris Davis
Ej Huang

data.text: you would look like a cyborg
data.author: Keith Ai

data.text: eeeekk!!!
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: Zinc - like the surfers use. I used to really suffer with the strong nz sun reflecting off the water. Nothing gets through a zinc sunblock
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: We use Da Brim helmet covers worked brilliant when we did a 6 month tour of Australia
data.author: Scott Fowler

data.text: Hi there ,I have that problem as well, unfortunately for me it's trial and error. Mineral based creme is usual thicker less running in to your eyes but messy and chalky white ,Sprays usually irritate eyes .I have yet to really find something suitable.
data.author: Casey Prigge

data.text: Zinc based sun cream Australian Life guards use it
data.author: Gerry Leonard

data.text: I think it needs to be reapplied. Currently using banana boat 60 spf in orange bottle. I usually never do reapply but my rides are under 4 hours. I‚Äôve been wearing long sleeve tech shirts to keep sun off my arms
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: Spf50. 10 min break every hour, reapply
data.author: Xavier Liebaert

data.text: I use a cycling cap, my beard, SPF lipgloss, and a small bottle of sunscreen that I bring with and reapply as necessary.
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: is this big sur?
data.author: Kelvin Bungcayao

data.text: yes
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: well now that I know someone else has the balls to go thru there now I'll be less scared to include that path into future trips
data.author: Kelvin Bungcayao

data.text: P20 sunfactor 50 apply 15 min before dressing works well all day on gingers
data.author: Ian Margerison

data.text: Por P20 is the best ever - my ginger ex could survive sailing in August in Greece on their factor 20 - as it is working constantly all day rather than lasting an hour/ re-applied after two it is really effective (and it‚Äôs sweatproof)
data.author: Gregory W Nicholas

data.text: Yeah, Da Brim as already mentioned...and cycling cap for my, ahem, bald spot. Sun screen for arms and back of hands
data.author: Gerry Kingsley

data.text: We use this

data.text: No bike lane on hwy 1.
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: I do a ton of biking in Phoenix Arizona and can‚Äôt say enough aboutÔøº my ‚ÄúDa Brim‚Äù hat. It attaches to my helmetÔøº. Love it! Hundreds of hours of biking in the shade :-)Ôøº
data.author: Joseph Heidenreich

data.text: Yeah, I live in Goodyear myself. Slather on the zinc sunscreen when I go out.
data.author: David Jones

data.text: Alcohol based spray sun screen works very well against sweat. Is this Big Sur btw?
data.author: Deling Ren

data.text: I started using a 90s style visor protect my face a bit. And it works when it is raining to keep the rain out of my eyes.
data.author: James Edwards

data.text: I hate sunscreen and I'm a ginger. I wear a long sleeve moisture wicking shirt, neck gator that I can pull up on my face. I also try to ride early mornings and late afternoons when the uv rays are weakest.
data.author: Mike Cook

data.text: Suncreen only works for a couple of hours. You have to keep reapplying it.
data.author: Scott England

data.text: Sol sunscreen is legit
data.author: Kit Wren

data.text:
https://www.coolnes.com/product/coolnes-noseshield/
CoolNES-NoseShield - CoolNES
coolnes.com
data.author: David Rossi

data.text: I wear a sun hat. That‚Äôs it.
data.author: Solita Work

data.text: I wear long sleeve shirts and long pants, even when it's hot. Basically only my face, neck and hands are exposed. And I don't use sunscreen creams or a hat of any sort. No sunglasses either. Well, I am a bit dark skinned to begin with, but I also take breaks now and then in the shade, and longer breaks around noon to afternoon.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Glasses over the gator
data.author: John Mendivil

data.text: I wear BUFF scarves, and I just realized a gator is a gaiter or however you spell it. Same thing. The one I wear most is cheap lycra balaclavas from Aliexpress.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: Long sleeved, hooded, UPF 20, hi-viz colored, sweat wicking thin summer shirt. Not a sweat shirt. It keeps me cool by evaporation of either sweat or water sprinkled on. This shades my torso, arms, neck, & head. I cover my hands with fingerless gloves similar to the shirt. I made an overhanging bill for my helmet that hangs down almost to eye level, so I can tilt my head forward to block a forward sun all the way down to the horizon.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: DONT USE SUNSCREEN, it causes cancer. Just cover up with clothes
data.author: Gervase Barnes

data.text: Zinc and I try not to cycle from around 10 to 2 or 3
data.author: Merran Cowper

data.text:
Long billed (brimmed) hat with removable neck protection works well. The key is a long billed hat like this. https://www.amazon.com/Stone-Age-Adjustable-Ballcap-Detachable/dp/B06XTH4WVN/ref=sr_1_42?keywords=Long+Brim+Fishing+Hat&qid=1660374378&sr=8-42
Stone Age Adult Long Billed Adjustable Ballcap W/Detachable Neck Flap (One Size)
amazon.com

data.text: Shade from a tree
data.author: Steven Bowie

data.text: Zinc
data.author: Steve Thorp

data.text: How do those bags fit on the front, you can never see behind them to work it out üòÇ
data.author: Simon Jap McClelland

data.text: Whilst living in Oz Zinc was very popular, they even produced it in fluoro colours for the Surfie Dudes and young children, top of your ears are susceptible also. Slip ,Slap ,Slop.
data.author: Roland Bryans

data.text: Nivea factor 50. Reapply halfway through the day. Serves well for a 9 hour full day of sweaty riding.
data.author: Jochen Siegenthaler

data.text: Peak cap
data.author: Richard Gould

data.text: I just use my child's waterproof factor 50
data.author: Ioan Said

data.text: Hard hat sunscreens from Amazon $5!
data.author: James Hoffman

data.text: That‚Äôs why I always get a helmet with a visor attachment. Many ‚Äúroadies‚Äù don‚Äôt like visors because there is added air resistance and slows their Strava times and then they won‚Äôt be KOM. Haha!
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: I had a really good experience with my Da Brim (likes hat brim that fits around/over your helmet) combined with a lip balm with sun screen in it like Chap Stick.
data.author: Elizabeth Wiczer

data.text: Da brim(helmet hat), sunglasses, toob(neck gaiter), long sleeved jersey, bike gloves and a beard. I tend to forget to apply sunscreen, but I don't forget to wear clothes üòÄ
data.author: Richard Neville

data.text: I use sunscreen for my face and arms an such. for my back of neck under my helmit I use a lite ball cap on backwrds so the bill is protecting my neck. this has stoped my sunburn issues on my neck. Hope this helps.
data.author: Bill Wilt

data.text: thats owesome you bike all the way to bixby bridge..
data.author: Kiko Prado

data.text: I live in NZ where there is always tons of sunburning if you do not take care. I never put sunscreen on above the eyes,it sweats into your eyes and you cannot see anything. Took me a few years to figure out that even the best sunscreens still hurt your eyes, I use a face specific sunscreen below the eyes and on the nose. And lather it on my neck and ears. AND a peaked cap under my helmet to shade my brow etc.
data.author: Douglas Thompson

data.text: that little cap under the helmet, great idea. Also prevents the sun from burning the skin under the helmet. And you don't really need sunglasses. Prevents you from developing that panda image. Apply 50 strength sunscreen on nose, ears, lower face regularly.
data.author: Otto Kos

data.text: Buff, cap.
data.author: Paul Hamon
Paul Hamon

data.text: Top of head, ears and above eyes = Helmet with brim and/or paired with a cap with long tail for neck. Eyes= wraparound glasses Face below eyes= sunblock or zinc cream Limbs=light wicking base layers in white
data.author: Ian Haigh
